keyTakeAways: Colombian appeals court overturns ex-President Alvaro Uribe’s conviction for fraud and bribery, citing structural deficiencies in the original ruling.
Uribe’s conviction in July 2025 was the first time a former Colombian president was found guilty of a crime, making it historically significant.
The ruling has intensified political divisions, with critics accusing the judiciary of covering up right-wing paramilitary abuses and historical complicity.
Current President Gustavo Petro condemned the decision as an attempt to whitewash the history of political alliances with drug trafficking and violence.
Senator Ivan Cepeda plans to appeal the decision to the Supreme Court of Justice, signaling the case is far from concluded.
The outcome of this case is expected to heavily influence the 2026 Colombian presidential election, particularly as Uribe remains a popular figure among right-wing factions.
U.S. President Donald Trump and Secretary of State Marco Rubio have publicly expressed support for Uribe, criticizing Latin American judicial systems as biased against conservative leaders.
Petro has accused Trump of using Uribe’s legal case to advance U.S. influence in Colombia by aligning with right-wing political allies.
Uribe’s party, the Democratic Center, has announced plans for him to run for senator if legally permitted, indicating continued political engagement.
Senator Cepeda has signaled a presidential candidacy in 2026, adding further political dynamism to the electoral landscape.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A Colombian appeals court has overturned the 2025 conviction of former President Alvaro Uribe for fraud and bribery, citing structural flaws in the original judgment. The decision, which reversed a July 2025 conviction by Judge Sandra Liliana Heredia, has reignited political controversy, with critics accusing the judiciary of enabling right-wing paramilitary abuses. The case is deeply tied to Colombia’s long-standing conflict and political polarization, and its outcome is expected to heavily influence the 2026 presidential election. Key figures such as President Gustavo Petro and Senator Ivan Cepeda are actively engaged, with Cepeda planning to appeal to the Supreme Court. The decision has also drawn international attention, especially from U.S. political figures like Donald Trump and Marco Rubio, who have criticized Latin American judicial systems as biased against conservative leaders. As the case continues through the judicial system, it remains a pivotal moment in Colombia’s political history and a symbol of broader tensions between justice, power, and historical accountability.
title: Colombian appeals court strikes down ex-President Uribe’s conviction
